One even sent me a Facebook request. When I left I asked them to look out for her. She ended up being drugged and gang raped by them. They were never convicted.

I have two that come to mind. One was leaving a contract I had overseas early, I was young and struggling in a remote spot w/ no support. The second is that I wasn’t brave enough at 23 to go after the only guy who understood me, he made me old fashioned’s; one late happy hour, I let it slip how I felt about him to a guy next barstool, when he lamented that he was seeing someone, which i already knew, I defended myself in similar tone,  I wasn’t going to do anything about it, I just wish I would’ve told him something.
I regret losing my temper with my spouse in front of my children.  I yelled and broke a cup and threw a chair and I’ve not done it since...but it remains a great source of shame and regret.

I regret rushing into things with someone else after my ex and I decided to take a break. Through this emotional decision and roller coaster, I entered a year full of unwanted drama and was trapped with a guy who was way too obsessive over me. It felt like I had lost control of myself and my life, and I experienced many frustrations throughout that year because I rebounded so quickly. My heart felt broken and as if it would not heal again. Instead, I wish I had taken the time to focus on myself and my healing process. I tend to have a hard time taking care of myself as I usually put others first. I now know the importance of looking after me.

Once upon a time I was a brand new financial advisor. Our company had a veteran advisor retire, or so I thought, but that was not the whole story. The backstory, which I found out later, is that he was a lazy advisor who was forced out because he was not being proactive with his clients. 

Every day I came to work early, stayed late, and prospected in ways that other new advisors were not willing to do. For example one time I went into a strip club with my business cards and on the back of them I wrote things like "I bet you make a lot of money, are you making smart decisions about your financial future? Give me a call." on the back of the card. I am sure you can guess how many calls I received.

When this advisor left I began calling his clients and having them come in to meet me. I saw they were in investments that might not have been appropriate, lack of diversification, higher ongoing costs, etc.

In the early 2000's I committed financial infidelity. I hid credit card debt from my husband so I could buy things to make myself look more successful than I was. Then I lost my job and we had to downsize our house because we had no emergency savings (because of me.) I started a new career moving from corporate finance (something I hated but did for 25 years because I loved the money and prestige.) to marketing. That was my first degree and something I should have stuck with. I was depressed and filled with shame. Started taking Xanax and proceeded to get TWO DUIs. One was dismissed but the second one stuck. My husband and I separated for 6 weeks in 2017. We have reunited, and I am finally making a good living doing what I ENJOY. My true gifting. I can see God's hand on me through this process. I know I am forgiven by the grace of God and my husband says he is proud of me. Yet I still cannot believe what I was capable of. And Satan is a crafty bastard. Thanks for listening!

I was 14.  I loved basketball and worked hard on my game.  I decided to try out for the 9th grade team. On try out day I waited in line and 2 guys said “what are you doing, you won’t make it”.  I thought for a minute, then went back to the locker room and changed clothes and went home.  Never tried.   That was the last time I never tried.   It still stings a bit.  I’ll never know.

My biggest regret is a path not taken. When I was 17, I was accepted to join an international performing group and was SO excited! It would have been for my senior year of high school; the program included an accredited high school-on-the-road in which I would have had real-life learning experiences. My parents, without any real exploration of the program, decided they wouldn't let me go. Even though I was devastated, I was brought up to not challenge my parents. So I didn't push them to reconsider, and I didn't go. Years later I finally got the nerve to ask why; the response was "we were concerned about your education." I know I would have received an amazing education that year; at the time they didn't even attempt to learn the details. It was a pivotal moment in my life trajectory, and it wasn't even my choice. While I don't dwell on it, I can't help wonder what my life would have been like had I been able to have this experience. Not going is the biggest regret of my life.

I burned out my client base so many times and got sued for overtrading [churning] the clients' accounts. 
I also NEVER received 1 referral from a client. Why should they give me a referral when I burned them all.
Why did I do this?
1. the fast buck/quick way to earn a lot of commission dollars
2. encouragement from management...the more business you did, the more rewards they would give me. (e.g., a personal assistant, cold-callers, private office, tickets to shows, Trips for Vacation, etc)

My "big regret" is when I was young I didn't take the time to talk with my father more.  He was a lot older than any of my friends' fathers and was a quiet gentle man who didn't talk much. I do wish I'd coaxed him to telling me more stories about his past life.  Unfortunately I was always crazy busy with teenage stuff and then went away to college, graduated, married and soon thereafter my father died.  FYI: I've always made my 'big regret' known to my own kids & grandkids. And they would lovingly humor me (with an occasional rolling-of-the-eyes) by listening to my stories.  Years ago, for a Christmas present, my teenage son gifted me a blank notebook and requested that I write stories in it that pop into my head when he wasn't there to listen to them ... and which I might forget to tell him.  Fast forward to now that he has own two children, he tells them of my "big regret".  Of course there's the occasional eye-roll  ... but they lovingly listen as he launches into his stories.
